DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN-FUNDED GRANT AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT THE PROPOSED INTERIM DRINKING WATER PROGRAM (IDWP).THIS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE TRAINING AND EDUCATION TO APPROXIMATELY 280 FARMWORKER FAMILIES RESIDING IN TWENTY SMALL MOBILE HOME PARKS KNOWN AS 'POLANCOS'. THESE 'POLANCOS' EXPERIENCE WATER CONTAMINATION, INCLUDING ARSENIC AND FLUORIDE, THAT IS PRESENT IN THE MOBILE HOME PARK WELLS. THE MAIN PROGRAM ACTIVITIES ARE COMMUNITY OUTREACH, PLANNING, AND ORGANIZING, ALL OF WHICH WILL FACILITATE A NEEDS ASSESSMENT TO FURTHER DEVELOP THE UNDERSTANDING OF EACH COMMUNITY'S PRIORITIES AND CHALLENGES. OUR ESTABLISHED NETWORK RELATIONSHIPS WITH POLANCO PARKS ARE THE IDEAL CONDITIONS TO CONDUCT DOOR-TO-DOOR CANVASING TO BEGIN DEVELOPING THE IDWP. THIS EFFORT WILL BE AIDED BY DISTRIBUTION OF FLYERS, NEWSLETTERS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS TO INFORM THE COMMUNITY. THESE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES HAVE PROVEN EFFECTIVE IN ENCOURAGING FAMILIES TO PARTICIPATE IN THE IDWP. FAMILIES WILL SIGN A LETTER OF AGREEMENT TO MOVE TOWARDS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF POINT-OF-USE WATER FILTRATION UNITS. ALL THESE MILESTONES WILL ENSURE GREATER PROGRAM PARTICIPATION TO INCREASE WATER CONTAMINATION KNOWLEDGE, COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL DRINKING WATER REGULATIONS, BOOST EQUITY  THROUGH RESOURCE ACCESSION, IMPROVE COMMUNITY MEMBERS QUALITY OF LIFE, AND PROGRESS TOWARDS THE MAIN WATER CONSOLIDATION GOAL WITH LOCAL MUNICIPAL SERVICES.
PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO 03/01/2023.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE:
1: COMMUNITY OUTREACH TO APPROXIMATELY 20 POLANCO MOBILE HOME PARKS; INFORM RESIDENTS REGARDING COMPLIANCE WITH SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT (SDWA) REGULATIONS.

2: PROVIDE EDUCATION ABOUT INTERIM SOLUTIONS FOR DRINKING WATER TO COMPLY WITH THE SDWA; INTRODUCE THE IDWP IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR THE INSTALLATION OF POINT-OF-USE WATER FILTRATION USING REVERSE OSMOSIS TECHNOLOGY.

3: PROVIDE TRAINING AND INFORMATION REGARDING WATER SAMPLING AND REPORTING; ESTABLISH COMPLIANCE PROCESS, INCLUDING SCHEDULING OF WATER SAMPLING.

4: PROVIDE REPORTING OF INSTALLED UNITS EVIDENCED BY EPA TRACKING FORMS INCLUDING WATER SAMPLING AND REPORTINGSUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 

1. DEVELOPMENT OF A NEEDS ASSESSMENT AND WORKPLAN: WORK IN COORDINATION WITH POLANCO COMMUNITIES TO IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE CHALLENGES AND NEEDS FOR THE PROJECT; AND EXPLAIN POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS.

2. SCOPING: CONDUCT COMMUNITY CANVASSING TO NOTIFY RESIDENTS OF THE IDWP AND TO COLLECT ACCURATE POPULATION DATA.

3. COMMUNITY OUTREACH: UTILIZE AND PREPARE OUTREACH STRATEGIES AND MATERIALS, SUCH AS PUBLISHED MATERIALS, FLYERS, NEWSLETTERS, AND HANDOUTS, TO INFORM AND EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT DRINKABLE WATER. OUTREACH INCLUDES A PHASED APPROACH TO INTRODUCE THE COMMUNITY TO THE IDWP; PRESENT PROJECT IMPACTS, CONSOLIDATION, BENEFITS, AND COSTS AS WELL AS OPTIONS FOR INTERIM SOLUTIONS; AND DISCUSS THE PARTICIPATING RESIDENTS RESPONSIBILITIES. 

4. LETTERS OF AGREEMENT TO RECEIVE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE: OBTAIN LETTER OF AGREEMENT FROM EACH MOBILE HOME PARK OWNER OR INDIVIDUAL HOMEOWNER WHO INTENDS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE IDWP PROGRAM.

5. SCHEDULE DEVELOPMENT: DEVELOP A SCHEDULE OF INSTALLATIONS, AFTER LETTERS OF AGREEMENT ARE SIGNED, AND INSTALL UNITS FOR RESIDENTS

THE BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF POLANCOS.
TO BUILD AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING FOR RESIDENTS, RECREATIONALISTS, AND VISITORS OF THE ANIMAS RIVER WATER QUALITY CONDITIONS AND INFORM SAFE RECRE

DESCRIPTION:THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, NATIONAL RURAL WATER ASSOCIATION WILL DELIVER A TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FOR SMALL PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS TO PROMOTE COMPLIANCE WITH THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT (SDWA) AND IMPROVE FINANCIAL AND MANAGERIAL CAPACITY.ACTIVITIES:TRAINING SPECIALISTS WILL PROVIDE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SMALL PWSS TO INCREASE TECHNICAL, MANAGERIAL, AND FINANCIAL CAPACITY, IMPROVE THEIR ABILITY TO ACHIEVE AND MAINTAIN SDWA COMPLIANCE, AND INCREASE ACCESS TO SAFE DRINKING WATER. TRAINING SPECIALISTS WILL PROVIDE TRAINING CLASSES WITH APPROVED CONTINUING EDUCATION UNITS (CEUS) TO PROMOTE OPERATOR LICENSURE AND IMPROVE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT - KEY COMPONENTS OF PWS SUSTAINABILITY. THIS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON, ONSITE TA AND IN-PERSON/HYBRID TRAINING COURSES FOR OPERATORS, MANAGERS, AND DECISION-MAKERS ASSOCIATED WITH SMALL PWSS THAT SERVE POPULATIONS OF UNDER 10,000 PEOPLE IN SMALL, RURAL, AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:PER THE PROJECT PROPOSAL, SUBAWARDS WILL BE USE TO SUPPORT STATE OFFICES/AFFILIATES FOR TRAINING AND ON-SITE ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES.

OUTCOMES:NATIONAL RURAL WATER ASSOCIATION WILL PRESENT TRAININGS AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ON TOPICS RELEVANT TO THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT AND NATIONAL PRIMARY DRINKING WATER REGULATIONS COMPLIANCE, AND TECHNICAL, MANAGERIAL, AND FINANCIAL CAPACITY.
OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 
- A STRENGTHENED WORKFORCE AT PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS (PWS) THROUGH AN INCREASE IN THE KNOWLEDGE AND COMPETENCY OF SMALL PWS OPERATORS AND DECISION-MAKERS IN A MANAGERIAL, OPERATIONAL, AND FINANCIAL CAPACITY. 
- IMPROVED DRINKING WATER QUALITY AND BETTER PROTECTION OF PUBLIC HEALTH, REFLECTED IN AN INCREASED NUMBER OF SMALL PWSS IN COMPLIANCE WITH SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT (SDWA) REQUIREMENTS AND NATIONAL PRIMARY DRINKING WATER REGULATIONS. 
- AN INCREASED LEVEL OF FINANCIAL CAPACITY, MEASURED BY AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF SMALL PWSS ACCESSING FUNDS THROUGH DWSRFS. 
- A MEASURABLE IMPROVEMENT IN THE PERFORMANCE OF SMALL PWSS WHERE OPERATIONAL CHANGES OR OTHER RECOMMENDATIONS WERE IMPLEMENTED FOLLOWING A SYSTEM DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATION. 
- AN INCREASE IN THE KNOWLEDGE AND COMPETENCY OF SMALL PWS OPERATORS AND DECISION-MAKERS IN REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS AND EFFECTIVE COMPLIANCE STRATEGIES. 
- AN INCREASED LEVEL OF EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS AND RESILIENCY IN SMALL PWSS FROM COMPLETING RISK AND RESILIENCE ASSESSMENTS. 
- AN INCREASED NUMBER OF SMALL SYSTEMS WITH HEALTH-BASED REPORTING AND MONITORING VIOLATIONS RETURNING TO COMPLIANCE. 
- IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE AND COMPETENCY OF SMALL PWS OPERATORS, LEADING TO SDWA COMPLIANCE OR MAKING SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS TOWARD COMPLIANCE. 
- INCREASED STRENGTH AND SUSTAINABILITY OF THE WATER INDUSTRY WORKFORCE AS MEASURED BY AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF OPERATORS OBTAINING AND MAINTAINING CERTIFICATION. 
- MEASURABLE PROGRESS TOWARD ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND EQUITY GOALS, WITH AN INCREASED NUMBER OF PEOPLE RECEIVING THE SAME DEGREE OF PROTECTION FROM ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH HAZARDS, AND EQUAL ACCESS TO THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS TO HAVE A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH TO LIVE, LEARN, AND WORK. 
BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE:
OPERATORS, MANAGERS, AND DECISION-MAKERS ASSOCIATED WITH SMALL PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS THAT SERVE POPULATIONS OF UNDER 10,000 PEOPLE IN SMALL, RURAL, AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES.

DESCRIPTION:IN COLLABORATION WITH ITS PARTNERS, RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP INCORPORATED WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL, MANAGERIAL, AND FINANCIAL CAPACITY-BUILDING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR OPERATORS, BOARD MEMBERS, AND MANAGERS OF TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL SMALL COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS, NON-TRANSIENT NON-COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS, AND TRANSIENT NON-COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS. THE OBJECTIVE IS PROTECTING HUMAN HEALTH THROUGH IMPROVED COMPLIANCE AND LONG-TERM SYSTEM SUSTAINABILITY. THE END RESULTS WILL INCLUDE AN INCREASED NUMBER OF SMALL PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS IN REGULATORY COMPLIANCE OR MAKING SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS TOWARD COMPLIANCE; INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND COMPETENCY OF OPERATORS, MANAGERS, AND BOARD MEMBERS; INCREASED NUMBER OF OPERATORS ACQUIRING, MAINTAINING, AND ADVANCING THEIR CERTIFICATION; AND AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF SYSTEMS THAT HAVE ADOPTED SUSTAINABLE FINANCE AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.ACTIVITIES:THROUGH ITS NETWORK OF MORE THAN 350 FIELD-BASED STAFF AND PROJECT PARTNERS, THE RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP INCORPORATED TEAM WILL PROVIDE TRAINING IN ALL 50 STATES, THE FIVE US TERRITORIES, AND IN TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, USING BOTH IN-PERSON AND REMOTE/ONLINE METHODS. RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP INCORPORATED WILL DEPLOY TRAINING METHODS THAT INCLUDE: 1) TRADITIONAL IN-PERSON, INSTRUCTOR-LED TRAINING; 2) LIVE, INSTRUCTOR-LED ONLINE TRAINING; 3) WEBINAR PRESENTATIONS OFFERED LIVE AND RECORDED FOR LATER ON-DEMAND VIEWING; 4) MICROLEARNING (SHORT PIECES OF ON-DEMAND CONTENT THAT CAN BE QUICKLY AND CONVENIENTLY CONSUMED); AND 5) ELEARNING, WHICH INCLUDES ONLINE/ON-DEMAND SELF-PACED MODULES. RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP INCORPORATED WILL ALSO DEVELOP BLENDED LEARNING TRAININGS THAT COMBINE SELF-PACED, ON-DEMAND MATERIALS WITH LIVE, INSTRUCTOR-LED TRAINING.SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROVIDING TECHNICAL, MANAGERIAL, AND FINANCIAL (TMF) CAPACITY-BUILDING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.OUTCOMES:THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE: OPERATORS, BOARD MEMBERS, AND MANAGERS OF TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL SMALL COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS, NON-TRANSIENT NON-COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS, AND TRANSIENT NON-COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES: - INCREASED NUMBER OF SMALL PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS (NON-TRIBAL, TRIBAL, COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM/NON-COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS) IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT OR MAKING SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS TOWARD COMPLIANCE AS INDICATED BY MEASURED PERFORMANCE, REDUCED ENFORCEMENT PRIORITY STATUS, OR OTHER INDICATORS IN ITS DATA COLLECTION SYSTEM (AND FINAL TECHNICAL, MANAGERIAL, FINANCIAL ASSESSMENTS; - INCREASED NUMBER OF SYSTEMS THAT HAVE ADOPTED SUSTAINABLE OR RESILIENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AS A PART OF THEIR OPERATIONS AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES; - INCREASED TECHNICAL, MANAGERIAL, FINANCIAL CAPACITY OF SMALL SYSTEM OPERATORS AND MANAGERS TO DIAGNOSE AND CORRECT THE CAUSES FOR COMPLIANCE FAILURES AND TO INCREASE SUSTAINABILITY AND RESILIENCY; - INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND COMPETENCY OF BOARD MEMBERS TO MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE AND TO SUSTAIN SYSTEMS OVER TIME; - INCREASED NUMBER OF SYSTEMS WITH UPDATED CERTIFIED RISK AND RESILIENCE ASSESSMENTS AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLANS AS REQUIRED BY AMERICA'S WATER INFRASTRUCTURE ACT  SECTION 2013 FOR SYSTEMS SERVING OVER 3,300 POPULATION; AND - INCREASED NUMBER OF SMALL SYSTEMS WORKING TOGETHER IN ALL POSSIBLE FORMS OF UTILITY PARTNERSHIP TO IMPROVE EFFICIENCIES THAT ULTIMATELY ASSIST WITH REGULATORY COMPLIANCE, SUSTAINABILITY, AND IMPROVED PUBLIC HEALTH.

DESCRIPTION:THE RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP, INC. (RCAP), IN COLLABORATION WITH ITS SIX REGIONAL PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES UNLIMITED (CU), GREAT LAKES COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP (GLCAP), MIDWEST ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (MAP), RCAP SOLUTIONS (RSOL), RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE CORPORATION (RCAC), AND SOUTHEAST RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PROJECT (SERCAP), COLLECTIVELY, 'RCAP,' AND ITS STRATEGIC PARTNER, THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS (U OF I), WILL ASSIST SMALL PUBLICLY OWNED WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS (POTWS) AND COMMUNITIES/INDIVIDUALS SERVED BY ONSITE/DECENTRALIZED WASTEWATER SYSTEMS TO IMPROVE OPERATIONAL PERFORMANCE AND SYSTEM SUSTAINABILITY OVER THE LONG-TERM, WITH THE OBJECTIVE OF PROTECTING HUMAN HEALTH, ADVANCING ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND EQUITY, REVITALIZING COMMUNITIES AND IMPROVING COMPLIANCE, SUSTAINABILITY, AND RESILIENCY.ACTIVITIES:UNDER THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY, RCAP WILL PROVIDE IN-PERSON/REMOTE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (TA) TO: A) OWNERS, OPERATORS, AND MANAGERS OF SMALL PUBLICLY-OWNED WASTEWATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS; AND B) COMMUNITIES/INDIVIDUALS SERVED BY ONSITE/DECENTRALIZED WASTEWATER SYSTEMS. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE DIRECTED AT BOTH TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL SYSTEMS AND COMMUNITIES, ESPECIALLY IN SEVERELY IMPACTED AREAS.SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUB-AWARDEES WILL USE THEIR FUNDING FOR TYPICAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH TA AND TRAINING, SUCH AS SALARIES AND FRINGE, TRAVEL, AND REGULAR OPERATING EXPENSES. DURING THE 18-MONTH GRANT PERIOD, THE SUB-AWARDEES WILL HELP CONDUCT 12 TRAINING FOR SMALL, PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS (POTWS) AND ONSITE/DECENTRALIZED SYSTEMS. THE SUBAWARDEES WILL ALSO PROVIDE 29 TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES FOR SMALL POTWS AND IMPLEMENT 12 TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECTS IN DECENTRALIZED COMMUNITIES. THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS (U OF I) PARTICULARLY WILL ADD WASTEWATER-RELATED DOCUMENTS OR RESOURCES TO THE WEBSITE DATABASE. THEY ALSO PLAN TO POST TWO BLOG POSTS EACH OR A TOTAL OF 6 BLOGS EVERY QUARTER.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE 12 TRAINING AND 29 TA PROJECTS ON SMALL POTWS. ADDITIONALLY, RCAP WILL WORK ON IMPLEMENTING 12 TRAINING AND TA PROJECTS ON ON-SITE/DECENTRALIZED SYSTEMS. THE GRANTEE IS ALSO ANTICIPATING REGULAR MEETINGS WITH STATE PRIMACY AND REGULATORY AGENCIES TO ENSURE THE SMOOTH IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECTS. 

RCAP EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE AN INCREASED NUMBER OF WASTEWATER SYSTEMS THAT HAVE BEEN INVENTORIED, INSPECTED, OR HAVE MAINTENANCE SCHEDULES AND/OR MANUALS PRODUCED FOR NEW OR UPGRADED SYSTEMS THAT ARE THEN IN OR MOVING TOWARD COMPLIANCE AND ON A PATH TOWARD SUSTAINABILITY/RESILIENCY. ADDITIONAL OUTCOMES WILL BE MORE SYSTEM OWNERS PROPERLY OPERATING/MAINTAINING ONSITE/DECENTRALIZED WASTEWATER SYSTEMS, ULTIMATELY REDUCING MALFUNCTIONING SYSTEMS. THESE OUTCOMES CONTRIBUTE TO BETTER WATER QUALITY IN WATERSHEDS, WELLHEAD PROTECTION, PUBLIC HEALTH, AND AN EQUITABLE FOUNDATION FOR REVITALIZING COMMUNITIES.

MOST OF THE COMMUNITIES RCAP WILL ASSIST THROUGH THIS PROGRAM ARE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED AND HAVE POPULATIONS UNDER 1,500. THIS PROJECT WOULD SERVE ALL 50 STATES, THE U.S. TERRITORIES, AND TRIBAL LANDS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT ADDRESSES NATIONAL PRIORITY AREA 3: TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PRIVATE DRINKING WATER WELL OWNERS TO HELP IMPROVE WATER QUALITY. DRAWING ON NRWA'S VAST EXPERIENCE OF IMPLEMENTING GRASSROOTS AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS, THE NATIONAL RURAL WATER ASSOCIATION (NRWA) WILL IMPLEMENT AN INNOVATIVE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FOR PRIVATE WELL OWNERS (E.G., HOMEOWNERS AND GROUPS OF HOMEOWNERS WITH WELL(S) THAT SERVE FEWER THAN 25 PEOPLE AND CONTAIN LESS THAN 15 SERVICE CONNECTIONS). THIS POPULATION OF AMERICANS FACES WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY CHALLENGES AND ENCOUNTERS DIFFICULTY ACCESSING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.ACTIVITIES:NRWA TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDERS WILL CONDUCT A SERIES OF NATIONWIDE COMMUNITY WATER EVENTS, TRAINING WORKSHOPS, AND ONSITE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE VISITS. NRWA WILL USE IMPACTFUL LEARNING AIDS, SUCH AS THE ENVISION GROUNDWATER FLOW SIMULATION MODEL, TO EDUCATE PRIVATE WELL OWNERS ABOUT WATER QUALITY, WATER QUANTITY, OPTIONS FOR TESTING, AND THE OPTION TO CONNECT TO PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS.SUBRECIPIENT:NRWA HAS 49 STATE RURAL WATER AFFILIATES (STATE AFFILIATES) THAT SERVICE ALL 50 STATES AND U.S. TERRITORIES. THROUGH THE STATE AFFILIATES, NRWA WILL IMPLEMENT A COLLABORATIVE PLANNING PROCESS WITH STATE, TRIBAL, REGIONAL EPA, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS (I.E., THE COLLABORATIVE PLANNING PARTNERS). NRWA AND STATE AFFILIATES WILL SEEK INPUT FROM THE COLLABORATIVE PLANNING PARTNERS IN DRAFTING OPERATING PLANS THAT WILL PRIORITIZE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDS FOR PRIVATE DRINKING WATER WELL OWNERS IN TRIBAL AND OVERBURDENED COMMUNITIES. STATE AFFILIATES WILL CONSIDER ALL COMMENTS AND FINALIZE OPERATING PLANS WITHIN 45 DAYS OF THE GRANT AWARD. THE RESULTING PLANS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO ALL COLLABORATIVE PLANNING PARTNERS AND THE EPA PROJECT OFFICER. STATE AFFILIATES WILL COMMUNICATE PROGRAM RESULTS MID#8208;WAY AND AT THE END OF THE 12#8208; MONTH GRANT PERIOD. 

NRWA STATE AFFILIATES WILL DELIVER 75 OUTREACH/TRAINING EVENTS AND PROVIDE 200 HOURS OF FOLLOWUP TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE EVENTS' ATTENDEES. THESE SERVICES WILL EDUCATE HOMEOWNERS AND LOCAL DECISION#8208;MAKERS ON TOPICS SUCH AS WELL OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE, WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, SOURCE WATER PROTECTION, AND MANAGING CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS LIKE FLOODING AND DROUGHT. TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDERS WILL ALSO DISCUSS WATER TESTING OPTIONS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONNECTING TO PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS. 

NRWA PROVIDERS WILL PRODUCE 6 CASE STUDIES DETAILING MEANINGFUL COMMUNITY OUTREACH, TRAINING, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. THESE CASE STUDIES CAN BE USED AS STAND#8208;ALONE LEARNING TOOLS. NRWA AND STATE AFFILIATES WILL DISTRIBUTE THE CASE STUDIES IN PRINT AND DIGITALLY AND POST ON WEBSITES WHEN APPROPRIATE. 

NRWA AND ITS STATE AFFILIATES WILL PROMOTE EPA WEBINARS FOR WELL OWNERS THROUGH THE WEBINARS, SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN, AND NRWA'S QUARTERLY MAGAZINE, RURAL WATER, THAT IS DELIVERED TO APPROXIMATELY 22,000 SMALL AND RURAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS. DESCRIPTION:THE RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP, INC. (RCAP), IN COLLABORATION WITH ITS SIX REGIONAL PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES UNLIMITED (CU), GREAT LAKES COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP (GLCAP), MIDWEST ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (MAP), RCAP SOLUTIONS (RSOL), RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE CORPORATION (RCAC), AND THE SOUTHEAST RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PROJECT (SERCAP), COLLECTIVELY, 'RCAP,' WILL PARTNER WITH THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH ASSOCIATION (NEHA), THE NATIONAL GROUND WATER ASSOCIATION (NGWA), THE TEXAS AANDM UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION (TAMU), THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS (U OF I), AND THE WATER SYSTEMS COUNCIL (WSC) TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (TA) TO OWNERS AND MANAGERS OF PRIVATE DRINKING WATER WELLS AND THE STAKEHOLDER GROUPS THAT SERVE PRIVATE WELL OWNERS AND/OR ARE CHARGED WITH PROTECTING PUBLIC HEALTH.ACTIVITIES:WORK WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH A DIVERSE SET OF IN-PERSON AND REMOTE TA ACTIVITIES, TRAINING, AND OUTREACH THAT BLENDS TRADITIONAL AND INNOVATIVE APPROACHES AND CONCEPTS. OUTPUTS WILL INCLUDE FACE-TO-FACE AND INSTRUCTOR-LED ONLINE WORKSHOPS FOR PRIVATE WELL OWNERS, ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND PRIVATE WELL PROFESSIONALS, AND PRIVATE WELL STAKEHOLDERS; PRIVATE WELL ASSESSMENTS CONDUCTED AND WELL TESTING KITS DISTRIBUTED SO WELL OWNERS CAN TAKE ACTION ON IDENTIFIED WEAKNESSES AND/OR POTENTIAL CONTAMINATION; SELF-PACED ELEARNING COURSES FOR WELL OWNERS, ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS; CURRENT AND TRUSTED INFORMATION PROVIDED THROUGH A VARIETY OF COMMUNICATIONS CHANNELS; ON-DEMAND PHONE ASSISTANCE THROUGH A HOTLINE, ONLINE CHAT ASSISTANCE, AND RESPONSES TO ONLINE WELL OWNER QUESTIONS; A NATIONAL PRIVATE WELL WORKSHOP AND WORKING GROUP; WELL OWNER AND STAKEHOLDER NEWSLETTERS AND GUIDES; PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATIONS; AND PODCASTS, AMONG OTHERS. SUBRECIPIENT:RCAP HAS ASSEMBLED A TEAM OF PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS REPRESENTING A COMPREHENSIVE CROSS-SECTION OF PRIVATE WELL PROFESSIONALS TO ADVANCE THIS PROJECT. 1) U OF I WILL OPERATE THEIR PRIVATE WELL CLASS (PWC) PROGRAM THAT INCLUDES A SELF-PACED ONLINE LEARNING COURSE, WEBINARS, VIDEOS, PRESENTATIONS, AND DIRECT ASSISTANCE TO WELL OWNERS (U OF I WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE THROUGH ITS GROUNDWATER HYDROLOGISTS, GEOLOGISTS, CHEMISTS, AND ENGINEERS THAT CONDUCT APPLIED GROUNDWATER SCIENCE RESEARCH AND WATER TESTING. U OF I WILL PROVIDE TRAINING CEUS); 2) NGWA WILL PROVIDE FACE-TO-FACE EDUCATION FOR COMMUNITIES SERVED PRIMARILY BY PRIVATE WELLS AND EXTEND THEIR OUTREACH PROGRAM ON WELLOWNER.ORG THROUGH CONTINUED MAINTENANCE, UPDATED EDUCATION MATERIALS, AND DISTRIBUTION OF WELL OWNER GUIDE BOOKLETS (NGWA AND ITS NATIONWIDE MEMBERS REPRESENT DRILLERS, SCIENTISTS, ENGINEERS, AND OTHER RELATED INDUSTRY PROFESSIONALS, WHO WILL BE UTILIZED TO ASSIST IN AND PROMOTE THIS PROGRAM); 3) WSC WILL HOST AND DELIVER THEIR SUCCESSFUL WELL OWNER PHONE, EMAIL, AND CHAT HOTLINE AND CALL TRACKING SYSTEM (WSC AND ITS MEMBERS REPRESENT WATER WELL EQUIPMENT AND TECHNOLOGY MANUFACTURERS THAT WILL BE A RESOURCE FOR THE TEAM DURING THIS EFFORT); 4) NEHA WILL PROVIDE A FOUR-HOUR WORKSHOP ON PRIVATE WELL ISSUES RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE, SAFETY, SECURITY, AND MAINTENANCE THAT WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THE 2023 NEHA ANNUAL EDUCATION CONFERENCE CATERING TO ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND PRIVATE WELL PROFESSIONALS, PROVIDING CEUS TO ELIGIBLE ATTENDEES (NEHA AND ITS MEMBERS REPRESENT ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS WHO WORK WITH WELL OWNERS THROUGH HEALTH DEPARTMENTS AND OTHER PROGRAMS, INCLUDING STATE AFFILIATE ASSOCIATIONS. NEHA CREDENTIALS ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, A CREDENTIAL THAT REQUIRES CONTINUING EDUCATION TO MAINTAIN); AND 5) TAMU WILL BUILD ON THEIR WELLR ESPECTED AND COMPREHENSIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM, EXTENDING THEIR EXISTING WELL OWNER WORKSHOPS, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH TO PRIVATE WELL OWNERS IN TEXAS. OUTCOMES:THROUGH THESE EFFORTS, RCAP AND ITS ASSEMBLED PARTNERS WILL ACHIEVE NUMEROUS OUTCOMES THAT INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: INC

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW NRWA TO ADDRESS NATIONAL PRIORITY AREA 1 BY IMPLEMENTING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SMALL PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS TO ACHIEVE AND MAINTAIN SDWA COMPLIANCE, INCLUDING IMPROVING FINANCIAL AND MANAGERIAL CAPACITY IN ALL 50 STATES, TRIBAL NATIONS, AND U.S. TERRITORIES. NRWA'S PROPOSED PROGRAM BUILDS UPON SUCCESSFUL ELEMENTS AND METHODS OF THE USDA-FUNDED CIRCUIT RIDER PROGRAM TO CARRY OUT THESE OBJECTIVES.ACTIVITIES:NRWA'S APPROACH TO ADDRESSING NATIONAL PRIORITY AREA 1 AND EPA'S CURRENT PRIORITIES, INCLUDING ENSURING AND ADVANCING ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND EQUITY, REVITALIZING COMMUNITIES, AND PROTECTING HEALTH WHEN PROVIDING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (T/TA), INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC TASKS:
TASK 1: IMPLEMENT A DEFINED COLLABORATIVE PLANNING PROCESS WITH APPROPRIATE REGULATORY AUTHORITIES FOR EACH STATE, TRIBE, AND U.S. TERRITORY
TASK 2: PROMOTE AVAILABLE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SMALL PWS STAFF
TASK 3: PROVIDE INNOVATIVE COMPLIANCE ASSISTANCE TO SMALL PWS IN ALL 50 STATES, TRIBAL NATIONS, AND U.S. TERRITORIES
TASK 4: EXPAND ASSISTANCE FOR SMALL SYSTEMS TO DEVELOP CUSTOMER ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS AND TO ACCESS SRF FUNDS THROUGH THE INTENDED USE PLAN
TASK 5. EXPAND ASSISTANCE OPPORTUNITIES FOR TRIBALLY-OWNED AND OPERATED SYSTEMS, INDIGENOUS PEOPLES, MINORITY POPULATIONS, ALASKA NATIVE VILLAGES, COLONIAS, OVERBURDENED PWS, AND PWS IN U.S. TERRITORIES SERVING UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES
TASK 6: FOSTER THE TRANSFER OF RESULTS, SUCCESSFUL COMPLIANCE STRATEGIES, AND RESOURCES

DESCRIPTION:CLEAN WATER FUND'S (CWF'S) LEAD PIPE INVENTORY AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT PROJECT WILL OPERATE IN TWO PHASES. PHASE I WILL FOCUS ON CHELSEA AND MALDEN, MASSACHUSETTS, WHOSE EFFORTS TO ADDRESS THE PROBLEM OF LEAD SERVICE LINES (LSLS) IN DRINKING WATER ARE UNDERWAY. IN PHASE II, WORK WILL BE INITIATED IN 2-3 ADDITIONAL TARGET COMMUNITIES IN MASSACHUSETTS.ACTIVITIES:EXPECTED ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) PROVIDING MULTILINGUAL, CULTURALLY COMPETENT EDUCATION ABOUT THE HEALTH IMPACTS OF LEAD AND DRINKING WATER AND STEPS THAT INDIVIDUALS CAN TAKE TO REDUCE EXPOSURE BEFORE THE SOURCE ITSELF IS REMEDIATED; (2) CONDUCTING LSL ASSESSMENTS IN COLLABORATION WITH MUNICIPALITIES USING CUSTOMER-INITIATED LINE CHECKS FOLLOWED BY CONFIRMATION BY THE CITY; (3) IDENTIFYING ELIGIBLE CUSTOMERS TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF AVAILABLE ASSISTANCE MONEY AND DO TARGETED OUTREACH TO THAT POPULATION. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PARTICIPATING IN MEETINGS WITH CLEAN WATER FUND, THE CITY OF CHELSEA, AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS; RECRUITING PARTICIPANTS FOR MEETINGS; PROVIDING TRANSLATION SERVICES DURING EVENTS; AND CREATING AND TRANSLATING LEAD OUTREACH MATERIALS. OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD TO IMPROVED OUTCOMES IN GENERAL AWARENESS OF THE PREVALENCE OF LEAD IN DRINKING WATER, INCREASED EQUITY THROUGH MULTILINGUAL AND CULTURALLY COMPETENT MATERIALS AND PROGRAMMING, AND IMPROVED LSL INVENTORIES.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF CHELSEA, MALDEN, AND ADDITIONAL TARGET EJ COMMUNITIES IN MASSACHUSETTS.

DESCRIPTION:THE 'LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY' PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF LEAD IN DRINKING WATER, DEVELOP A SUSTAINABLE SOLUTION/SYSTEM FOR THE PUBLIC AND THE WATER DIVISION IN THE CITY OF FALL RIVER, MASSACHUSETTS TO IDENTIFY LOCAL LEAD SERVICE LINES, AND UPDATE/VERIFY THE CITY'S LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY. THIS PROJECT WILL BE FUNDED BY AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN (ARP) RESOURCES TO SUPPORT EDUCATION, OUTREACH, TRAINING AND ASSISTANCE THROUGH THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT TO ADDRESS LEAD IN DRINKING WATER TO BENEFIT RESIDENTS IN FALL RIVER, MASSACHUSETTS. WILL BUILD A NEW PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE CITY OF FALL RIVER AND RESIDENTS INCLUDING DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW INTERACTIVE LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY WEB VIEWER TOOL WHICH WILL BE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC, SHARE RESOURCES ON LEAD SERVICE LINE IDENTIFICATION AND RESOURCES TO ADDRESS ANY EXISTING LINES, AND GATHER PUBLIC INPUT TO INCORPORATE LOCAL KNOWLEDGE. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE PUBLIC AND THE CITY TO COMPLETELY REMOVE A SIGNIFICANT POTENTIAL SOURCE OF LEAD IN DRINKING WATER TO BENEFIT OF INDIVIDUALS INCLUDING SENSITIVE POPULATIONS OF CHILDREN IN AN OVERBURDENED AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY WITH ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE CONCERNS INCLUDING HIGH RISK FOR CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING, POVERTY, AND HIGH PERCENTAGE OF HOUSING BUILT BEFORE 1978.ACTIVITIES:THE 'LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY' PROJECT WILL GATHER EXISTING DATA ON LEAD SERVICE LINE LOCATIONS TO DEVELOP OF A NEW INTERACTIVE LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY WEB VIEWER TOOL WHICH WILL BE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC, SHARE RESOURCES ON LEAD SERVICE LINE IDENTIFICATION AND RESOURCES TO ADDRESS ANY EXISTING LINES, AND GATHER PUBLIC INPUT TO INCORPORATE LOCAL KNOWLEDGE. KEY ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ENSURING EXISTING DATA MEETS GEOSPATIAL REQUIREMENTS, DEVELOPING AND TESTING BETA VERSIONS OF THE INTERACTIVE LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY WE VIEWER TOOL, DEVELOPING A DATA COLLECTOR FORM TO GATHER PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE AND INCORPORATE INSPECTION DATA, DEVELOP STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES FOR THE TOOL AND ACCOMPANYING LEAD SERVICE LINE FORMS, AND BRING THE TOOL ON LINE FOR PUBLIC USE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP AND DISTRIBUTE PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH INFORMATION TO RAISE AWARENESS OF HOW TO IDENTIFY LEAD SERVICE LINES, PREVENT EXPOSURE TO LEAD IN DRINKING WATER, AND PRIORITIZE LEAD SERVICE LINE REPLACEMENT FOR MAXIMUM IMPACT TO BENEFIT LOCAL CHILDREN AT RISK FOR LEAD EXPOSURE. A KEY COMPONENT OF THE WORK IS ALSO DIRECT COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT TO SOLICIT INPUT ON THE NEW TOOL AND RESOURCES INCLUDING ATTENDING COMMUNITY MEETINGS TO REACH RESIDENTS WITH INFORMATION AND RESOURCE S.SUBRECIPIENT:OBJECTIVE 1 -LEAD SERVICE INVENTORY TOOL
TO PROVIDE A MORE COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE CITY AND ITS RESIDENTS TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL LEAD SERVICE LINES AND TO VERIFY PORTIONS OF THE EXISTING SERVICE LINE INVENTORY, AN INTERACTIVE LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY TOOL/MAP WILL BE CREATED. PRELIMINARY TASKS PLANNED FOR THE LEAD SERVICE INVENTORY TOOL ARE DOCUMENTED INCLUDE: ACQUIRING THE CITY'S EXISTING LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY AND OTHER POTENTIAL DATA, ASSESSING AND REPORTING ON THE DATA AND INFORMATION TO ENSURE THAT IT SUPPORTS THE GEOSPATIAL AND DATA INTEGRITY NEEDS OF THE OBJECTIVE, WITH SIGNIFICANT CHANGES OR EFFORTS REQUIRED TO SUPPORT THE NEEDS REPORTED AND DISCUSSED WITH THE CITY PRIOR TO PROCEEDING TO SUBSEQUENT STEPS; BEGINNING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE INTERACTIVE LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY WEB VIEWER TOOL; DEVELOPING A AGIS-BASED LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY DATA COLLECTOR FORM FOR FIELD VERIFICATION/INSPECTION OF POTENTIAL LEAD SERVICE LINES; AND DELINEATING AND PROVIDING A STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES FOR BOTH THE TOOL AND ACCOMPANYING LEAD SERVICE LINE INVENTORY FORM TO THE CITY TO ENSURE PROPER USE.
